title: ELI5: Why do unopened plastic water bottles do that "squishy ... - Reddit
body: Meaning, water that evaporates inside the bottle can actually slowly crawl through the wall material and evaporate on the outside. This slowly decreases the amount of water inside, reducing the internal pressure. Again, allowing squishing. could be manufacturing issues.
readable_content:
- mcmenrm (2019-12-08): 
ELI5: Why do unopened plastic water bottles do that “squishy” thing?
I really hope someone knows what I’m talking about, as it’s extremely hard to explain without visual aid.

- sillystringmassacre (2019-12-08): 
I’ve always assumed it was just a thinner type of plastic. But interested to hear from someone who actually knows lol

- oopleeaze (2019-12-08): 
I got one of those last week. I think it is because it got squished somehow just as the lid was put on. When I opened it, it had less water than the other bottles. Same thing though, plastic returned to original strength.

- yadayadatennessee (2019-12-08): 
Like when you try to open it it just squishes?

- ahmadove (2019-12-08): 
I think you're referring to a phenomenon called panel sink. There are multiple reasons for it:
... (detailed explanation)

- Commander-Grammar (2019-12-08): 
It’s either pressure or temperature change. If it’s bottled at a higher altitude it will compress a little bit as it’s shipped to you. When you open it, the slight vacuum is relieved and the bottle appears to get stronger as it returns to its intended shape. Same thing would happen with a temperature change. Look up pictures of potato chip bags at high altitude. It’s the opposite of that.
